name: Kepler-116
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-116 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-116 is a star with 1.879999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.45 times its radius. It is located 3202.98 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-116 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-116 b

Kepler-116 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.97 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-116.

The mass of Kepler-116 b is 18.39 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-116 b is 3.42 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-116 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-116 c

Kepler-116 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.07 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-116.

The mass of Kepler-116 c is 7.09 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-116 c is 2.3 that of Earth. At 7.09 Earth masses, Kepler-116 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-116, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
